title: 106_hr1557
content: The Act titled "Maritime Administration Authorization Act for Fiscal Years 2000 and 2001" authorizes appropriations for fiscal years 2000 and 2001. Funds are authorized for the Department of Transportation's Maritime Administration for operations, training, and loan guarantee costs. $72,164,000 is allocated for the fiscal year 2000, $6,000,000 for guaranteed loans, and $3,893,000 for administrative expenses. Additional funds are available as needed for the fiscal year 2001. AMENDMENTS TO TITLE XI OF THE MERCHANT MARINE ACT, 1936. The Merchant Marine Act, 1936 is amended to authorize the Secretary to hold proceeds of guaranteed obligations in escrow for vessel construction. Funds can only be released after the obligor pays their share of the construction costs. The Merchant Marine Act, 1936 is amended to allow the Secretary to hold funds in escrow for vessel construction, releasing them only when necessary for payments related to the vessel or approved costs. "SEC. 1109. RESERVE FUNDS AND COLLATERAL ACCOUNTS." Establishment of a deposit fund in the Treasury for cash belonging to an obligor with a security interest. The Secretary and obligor must enter into an agreement governing deposits, withdrawals, and investment of the cash. The Secretary is authorized to invest and reinvest cash in a reserve fund or collateral account. The Secretary can reinvest cash from a reserve fund or collateral account in US obligations. Cash balances exceeding current needs are kept as uninvested funds, with the Treasury paying interest. Withdrawal of deposited cash requires Secretary's consent. The Secretary can offset cash and income against defaulting obligors. Income from reserve funds or collateral accounts can be paid according to the agreement terms. AMENDMENTS TO TITLE IX OF THE MERCHANT MARINE ACT, 1936. Section 903 added for documentation of certain dry cargo vessels. The restrictions of section 901(b)(1) of this Act do not apply to dry bulk vessels and breakbulk vessels over 5,000 deadweight tons constructed, reconstructed, or acquired in a foreign shipyard within one year of enactment and transferred to the United States flag registry. Repairs and work must be done in a US shipyard, comply with specific standards, and not be granted approval under section 9(e). The Merchant Marine Act, 1936, has been amended to extend the time periods for certain provisions regarding vessel construction and acquisition. The restrictions on vessels under section 901(b)(1) do not apply to specific types of vessels meeting certain criteria. SEC. 5 extends war risk insurance authority to June 30, 2005. SEC. 6 requires the Secretary of Transportation to report on maritime activities by April 1 of each odd-numbered year. SEC. 7 transfers ownership of the Jeremiah O'Brien to the National Liberty Ship Memorial, Inc.
